definition: Wang Yangming (1472-1529), Ming dynasty Neo-Confucian philosopher, influential in the School of Mind 心學|心学[xin1 xue2]
surname Wang
king or monarch/best or strongest of its type/grand/great
to rule/to reign over
positive (electric.)/sun/male principle (Taoism)/Yang, opposite: 陰|阴[yin1]
Ming Dynasty (1368-1644)/surname Ming/Ming (c. 2000 BC), fourth of the legendary Flame Emperors, 炎帝[Yan2 di4] descended from Shennong 神農|神农[Shen2 nong2] Farmer God
bright/opposite: dark 暗[an4]/(of meaning) clear/to understand/next/public or open/wise/generic term for a sacrifice to the gods

sentences.english: The relation between reason and mind is the core issue of Wangyangming's philosophy.
sentences.chinese: 心与理的关系是王阳明哲学的核心问题。

sentences.english: Wang Yangming's poetry can be divided three periods in coincidenee with his three changes of academic interests.
sentences.chinese: 王阳明诗歌随其学术的三变，可分为三个阶段。

sentences.english: Epistemology is also the foundation and the arcanum of Wang's theory as a whole.
sentences.chinese: 认识论部分是整个王阳明哲学的基础和奥秘所在。

sentences.english: On this basis, this article summarise the characteristics of Wang's thought.
sentences.chinese: 在此基础上，本文归纳提出王阳明思想的几个特点。

sentences.english: "Nothing exists beyond the mind" is an important idea in Wang Yangming's mental outlook system.
sentences.chinese: “心外无物”是王阳明心学体系的重要命题。

sentences.english: The evaluation of Wang Yangming's thought is an important aspect of Neo-Confucianism research.
sentences.chinese: 对王阳明思想的评价，是理学研究的重要内容。

sentences.english: He gave a new explanation to Wang Shouren′s theory of "agreement between knowledge and action."
sentences.chinese: 他对王阳明“知行合一”的观点进行了新的解释。

sentences.english: The second part: Emphatically elaborates Wang Yangming the basic content of"the unity of knowledge and action".
sentences.chinese: 着重阐述王阳明“知行合一”思想的基本内容。

definition: School of Mind/Neo-Confucian Idealistic School (from Song to mid-Qing times, c. 1000-1750, typified by the teachings of Wang Yangming 王陽明|王阳明[Wang2 Yang2 ming2])
Zhu Xi or Chu Hsi (1130-1200), also known as Master Zhu 朱子, Song dynasty Confucian writer and propagandist, founder of neo-Confucianism
scholar of the rationalist school of Neo-Confucianism 理學|理学[Li3 xue2]
Li Zhi (1527-1602), late Ming philosopher, historian and writer
Master Zhu, another name for Zhu Xi 朱熹
Cheng Hao (1032-1085), Song neo-Confucian scholar
to study the underlying principle to acquire knowledge (idiom); pursuing knowledge to the end
Yangming district of Mudanjiang city 牡丹江市, Heilongjiang
Wang Fuzhi (1619-1692), wide-ranging scholar of the Ming-Qing transition
Cheng Yi (1033-1107), Song neo-Confucian scholar
Confucianism

School of Principle/Neo-Confucian Rationalistic School (from Song to mid-Qing times, c. 1000-1750, typified by the teachings of Cheng Hao 程顥|程颢[Cheng2 Hao4], Cheng Yi 程頤|程颐[Cheng2 Yi2] and Zhu Xi 朱熹[Zhu1 xi1])
science
Zeng Guofan (1811-1872), Qing dynasty politician and military man
Mencius (c. 372-c. 289 BC), Confucian philosopher second only to Confucius/book of the same name, one of the classics of Confucianism
Gu Yanwu (1613-1682), late Ming and early Qing Confucian philosopher, linguist and historian, played a founding role in phonology of early Chinese, author of Rizhilu or Record of daily study 日知錄|日知录
Confucius (551-479 BC), Chinese thinker and social philosopher, also known as 孔夫子[Kong3 fu1 zi3]
